awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: User-Optimal Robotic Prosthesis Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this collaborative research project is to develop methods for optimizing robotic ankle-foot prosthesis function to the needs of individual users. The approach is to develop computational models of human-prosthesis interaction, use them to predict optimal device designs, and refine predictions in experimental work with a versatile robotic testbed. A detailed musculoskeletal simulation model of amputee locomotion, with tunable user-specific properties, will be generated. Numerical optimization will be used to obtain designs that are optimal for specific users and robust to small changes in user characteristics. Designs will be presented to human subjects with a "universal ankle-foot prosthesis emulator" in experiments that measure human energy use, muscle activity, body mechanics, and balance. Experimental results will be used to generate a model with high predictive accuracy. The research will result in an empirically-validated software tool for use by clinicians in prescribing optimal prosthesis designs to individual patients. 

If successful, the benefit of this research will be improved mobility and quality of life for individuals with amputation, achieved through a software tool that guides the design of user-optimal robotic ankle-foot prostheses. For example, the research is expected to quantify trade-offs between the costs and benefits of more powerful, but heavier and more expensive, motors, allowing optimal product design for individual users. The resulting devices are expected to reduce chronic problems with walking speed, fatigue, falls, and pain for more than 1 million people with lower-limb amputation in the United States. This methodology and infrastructure is also expected to improve biomechatronic design processes in general, for example improving the design of rehabilitation robots. The research will provide a collaborative, interdisciplinary environment for students, including minority, female, and disabled individuals.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Passive prostheses without robotic power have limited ability to help amputees. On the other hand, robotic lower-limb prostheses have the necessary capabilities to improve the walking performance of amputees. In this project, we used large-scale optimization calculations with computer models of amputees walking with robotic prostheses to provide insight into the factors that benefit amputee walking and to elaborate a computational approach to design of biorobotic devices that forcefully interact with a human.

 

Our focus was on robotic unilateral ankle-knee robotic prosthesis. Previous computer-simulation-based studies of unilateral amputees used walking motions obtained from non-amputee experiments. Here, in contrast, we allowed the computer model of the amputee to adapt to the power provided by the prosthesis, while simultaneously allowing the prosthesis to adapt to the amputee walking motion. Given that comfortable walking often correlates with minimal energy consumption for the human, we performed trajectory optimizations to minimize the human energy costs when walking with the prosthesis. Given that long battery life for the prosthesis requires minimizing the prosthesis electrical energy costs, we determined the lowest human effort for a given prosthesis effort, thereby characterizing the optimal trade-off between the two.

 

Such simultaneous optimizations of both the robotic prosthesis control and the amputee walking suggested that walking motion that minimized the amputee metabolic effort was substantially left-right asymmetric. That is, one leg does substantially more work than the other, spending more time on the ground, etc. Walking with left-right symmetry requires more effort, suggesting why amputees may walk with slightly asymmetry. The optimizations suggested that an optimized prosthesis can result in large reduction in amputee walking metabolic effort, reducing the effort below that of a non-amputee. Such large effort reductions and walking asymmetries were obtained at different walking speeds, different slopes, and different prosthesis masses, using alternate measures of walking effort, and for different human-body models, both complex multi-muscle computer models and much simpler models. This suggests robustness of the approach and results to different tasks or conditions or modeling details.

 

Given that the most practical ankle-foot robotic prosthesis apply torques based on current ankle state, we then investigated a range of such robotic prosthesis feedback control. Surprisingly, we found that many different relatively simple robotic prosthesis feedback controllers can produce metabolic reduction that has similar magnitudes (although slightly smaller than) allowing arbitrary prosthesis actuations. The energy-minimizing amputee walking motions with such simply-controlled prostheses were also left-right asymmetric, with symmetric walking motions being predicted to be more effortful. More surprisingly, we found that for such simple prosthesis controllers, more prosthesis work is not necessarily better, but that there is an optimal prosthesis work-level beyond which the human will require more work to walk. This was in contrast to when the prosthesis was allowed to have more complex control. Further, we find that controllers with certain simpler shapes produced higher effort reductions compared to more complex shapes (linear vs nonlinear).

 

Given that metabolic energy/effort minimization is considered to be a key feature of physiologically realistic human walking, we started with such minimization to simulate humans walking with a robotic prosthesis. As noted, such energy minimizations produced asymmetric walking gaits. Although human amputees walk slightly asymmetrically, minimizing energy while constraining symmetry produced walking simulations that were closer to those experimentally observed in amputees wearing robotic prosthesis. This could be because amputees may indeed have an explicit preference for such symmetric walking motions, as is generally thought in the rehab community, and because amputee walking may weight or prioritize other important aspects such as avoiding high stresses at the prosthesis-human interface. Larger stress asymmetry on the legs have also been argued to produce chronic conditions such as osteoarthritis. Indeed, incorporating this interfacial-stress-reduction into the human-prosthesis simulations gives rise to closer-to-symmetric but still-asymmetric walking motions that were closer to human behavior. We have systematically examined different cost terms in the optimization to better delineate the terms that best explain human amputee walking behavior. Based on our simulations, we suggest the use of the following novel prosthesis morphology: a robotic prosthesis on the affected leg and a robotic exoskeleton on the unaffected leg, so that both legs get assistance, naturally resulting in a more symmetric walking motion, equalizing and lowering the leg stresses, and resulting in substantial effort reductions.

 

Broader impacts of this project include use of such computationally-based approaches for other assistive and exoskeleton devices that exchange substantial mechanical energy with the human and the proposal of such novel exoskeleton-prosthesis morphologies to be explored in future projects. Our work was published at an open source journal and at a rehabilitation-specific journal, ensuring board accessibility and reaching the rehab scientists. We have presented our work at a robotics conferences, biomechanics conferences, at interdisciplinary conferences at the intersection of multiple communities, high school students, practicing prosthetists, and the general public, ensuring broad dissemination of the work and approach.
